headline.main: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give

docs.abstract: Dr Michael D Cantor letter comments on July 26 article on long-term care of elderly and difficulties of families struggling to support older relatives at home; says Govt must do more to insure that employers are also motivated to make is easier for workers to meet such responsibilities (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Long-Term Care for Elderly Merges Political and Personal'' (front page, July 26): Unfortunately, the Government policy for long-term care provides no support for those with savings while paying the full cost for those who are impoverished. Medicaid's effective penalty on savings has led some to exploit the system by divesting resources to qualify for the program.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Flo,'' an arthritic Medicare beneficiary, made her debut today in television commercials and newspaper advertisements, cautioning Congress about potential pitfalls in its effort to establish Medicare coverage for prescription drugs. The advertisements, financed mainly by drug companies, do not explicitly endorse or oppose President Clinton's proposal to offer drug coverage to all 39 million Medicare beneficiaries. On the one hand, Flo says Congress should ''help more seniors get prescription drug coverage.'' On the other, she declares, ''I don't want big government in my medicine cabinet!''

headline.main: Drug Company Ads Attack Medicare Coverage of Drugs

docs.abstract: New advertising campaign, financed mainly by drug companies, is cautioning Congress about potential pitfalls in its effort to establish Medicare coverage for prescription drugs, while not explicitly endorsing or opposing Pres Clinton's proposal to offer drug coverage to all 39 million Medicare beneficiaries; companies want to be sure Govt does not regulate drug prices or decide which medicines will be available to elderly or disabled (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in the Senate turned aside a Democratic plan today to limit the size of their proposed tax cut, even as centrists from both parties laid out a middle ground on which a compromise could eventually be reached. But as Republicans moved closer to Senate passage of the largest tax cut since 1981, they suffered a quirky procedural defeat that in theory would force them to rescind their tax reductions in 10 years, just after they would take full effect.

headline.main: G.O.P. Senators Repel an Effort To Scale Back Tax-Cut Proposal

docs.abstract: Republicans in Senate, on first day of debate on how large tax cut nation can afford in era of anticipated Federal budget surpluses, defeat Democratic plan to limit tax cut to $290 billion over 10 years on vote of 60 to 39; most Republicans and few Democrats are pushing for legislation that would cut taxes by $792 billion, using bulk of nearly $1 trillion in projected surpluses over next decade; Pres Clinton has threatened to veto Republican plan, and has countered it with offer of tax cut of up to $300 billion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report (front page, July 25) on a study outlining the unfair geographical distribution of the Medicare dollars used to train doctors. In a similar debate in 1996, Congress adopted a financing redistribution formula intended to rectify the unfair financing distribution for the Veterans Health Administration. Then, too, the Northeast was accused of receiving an unfair proportion of health care dollars.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As fascinating as the prospect of a planetarium at the new Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center sounds, it cannot replace high-quality health care (news article, July 24).

headline.main: Caring for the Elderly: The System's Got to Give

docs.abstract: Judy Sheridan-Gonzalez letter, commenting on July 24 article, questions spending $120 million on planetarium at new Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center, which is unable to provide enough care-givers to meet children's medical needs (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As fascinating as the prospect of a planetarium at the new Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center sounds, it cannot replace high-quality health care (news article, July 24).

docs.lead_paragraph: Many doctors responding to a new survey on managed care say some of their patients in the last two years have been denied coverage for a needed health service, from a prescription drug to a hospital stay. The survey, reflecting widespread discontent among doctors and nurses about the quality of health care under managed care plans, was released today in the midst of a struggle over patients' rights legislation on Capitol Hill. It was immediately criticized by spokesmen for health maintenance organizations and the insurance industry as flawed and exaggerated, and was just as quickly praised by the American Medical Association and the American Nurses Association.

headline.main: Many Doctors Tell of Denial Of Coverage by H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Survey conducted by Kasier Family Foundation finds discontent among many doctors and nurses over managed care, with many doctors saying patients have been denied coverage over last two years for needed health services; findings discussed; survey is released in midst of struggle over patients' rights legislation on Capitol Hill; is immediately criticized by health maintenance organizations and insurance industry as flawed and exaggerated, but is praised by American Medical Assn and American Nurses Assn (M)
